awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Multiscale Behavior of Triboelectric Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Triboelectricity is due to contact electrification, a phenomenon that occurs when nearly any combination of metal (conductor), semiconductor, or dielectric (insulator) materials come into contact. Previously, devices that utilize this principle were developed without understanding the fundamental mechanisms behind triboelectricity. The objective of this project is to fill in the knowledge gap about the true nature of triboelectricity through a combination of analytical models and experimental analysis. Potential transformative uses of this technology are to provide power sources to sensors and devices used in smart or intelligent packaging. Pharmaceutical packaging is predicted to be the fastest growing intelligent packaging market, with opportunities driven by the health care needs of the aging US population. Additionally, it is estimated that US businesses lose up to $250 billion of profit due to the counterfeit drug trade each year.  "Smart" packaging solutions include printed electronics, smart labels capable of illumination, temperature and humidity indicators, and radio frequency identification tags used for tracking and quick package identification. In addition, there is an array of sensors that can record forces in the distribution environment.  These devices share a need for power. The project also includes educational outreach activities in the form of interactive games based on triboelectric devices to engage K-12 students and to target under-represented minorities into pursuing a graduate degree in a science and technology and engineering and mathematics field.

The specific objectives of this project are to: develop predictive models of the molecular scale mechanism of charge transfer due to the contact electrification process, model the interplay of the macro and microscale properties of the device that effect its performance, study the effect of environmental conditions on the performance of these devices, and formulate multidimensional analytical models on the macroscopic behavior of flexible triboelectric generators that incorporate environmental effects, and microscale effects such as surface topography, local charge distribution, and real area of contact. The outcomes of this research will culminate in a test bed concept of a triboelectric foam composite to be utilized in smart packaging for concurrent energy scavenging and vibration suppression. The methodology in this project establishes a new paradigm on the design of triboelectric devices and marks the first systematic attempt to understand the behavior of triboelectric generators / sensors at multiple spatial scales. The insights gained from this research will culminate in system level understanding of these devices that will lead to a triboelectric genome of dielectric materials, surface treatments and textures, and elastic coupling elements to design a triboelectric device for a specific objective, whether it be sensing, energy scavenging or as an input to electronic devices. The project will also result in quantification of environmental condition on triboelectric devices, and phenomenologically modeling their effect.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary contribution of the Clemson University (CU) team on this collaborative grant was focused on major goal III: Elucidate the effect of environmental conditions, such as humidity and temperature, on the performance of these devices.


The orignial project timeline was 8/15/2017 - 7/31/2020.  Two, no-cost extensions where provided due to COVID 19 disruptions of lab and personel operations.  The deadline was extended to 7/31/2022.  The following is a summary of outcomes during the total duration of the project. 

The CU team designed, sourced, installed, and validated a custom environmental chamber that integrated with our existing electro-dynamic shaker.

The CU team worked closely with the Purdue University team in the development of a triboelectric device that could withstand a wide range of temperatures and relative humidity levels while attached to and excited by an electro-dynamic shaker for long durations. Several generations of such a device were developed with the final version made on a thermal printer from PLA. Four different combinations of triboelectric materials were explored in their performance.

The CU team develop and optimized a data acquisition system to record triboelectric energy generator (TENG) output voltage and generator acceleration.

The range and intervals for the environmental performance testing were established and the triboelectric generator vibration performance testing was completed.  The data analysis was performed and three important observations were made.  The details of the observations are reported in the significant findings section.

The humidity and temperature effect on the output behavior of the triboelectric generator was sucessfully characterized for the harmonic vibration input considered.

The following paper was presented at SMASIS 17 in Snowbird, UT resulting from preliminary work on this project.

  • Gauntt S., Batt G., Gibert J., Dynamic Modeling of Triboelectric Generators Using Lagrange’s Equation, ASME Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS 17), Snowbird, UT, September 18-20, 2017.

A graduate student, Andrea Fisher, was recruited, trained, and completed her M.S Thesis on this project.

A graduate student,Travis Vaughan, was recruited and trained to continue the research of M.S. Packaging Science student, Andrea Fisher, since she graduated in May 2019. (Travis completed a year of work on the project before leaving the research program for a job offer in industry.)

A graduate student, Madysn Cardinal, was recuited and trained to complete the development of a middle school science demonstration/class on triboelectric energy generators.  This demonstration/class was never delivered due to COVID school restrictions.

Sourced and purchased a 3D printer and computer workstation with the capability of printing electrical conductive materialsso we could continue devleopment of an optimized triboelectric generator. 

Assembled and trained a team of undergraduate students to develop a tribo-electric generator display for use at an industry trade show, PACK EXPO, in Las Vegas.  This display was presented throughout the event, September 27—29, 2021.

Submitted a manuscript of a journal paper for peer review.  This paper is currently under review. 

  • Barry, A.L, Batt, G.S., Gibert, J.M., Darby, D.O., The Application of Triboelectric Energy Harvester in the Packaged Product Vibration Environment, Packaging Technology and Science. Status: UNDER_REVIEW

Last Modified: 05/02/2024
Modified by: Gregory Batt
por.por_txt_cntn:
The primary contribution of the Clemson University (CU) team on this  collaborative grant was focused on major goal III: Elucidate the effect  of environmental conditions, such as humidity and temperature, on the  performance of these devices.



The orignial project timeline was 8/15/2017 - 7/31/2020. Two, no-cost extensions where provided due to COVID 19 disruptions of lab and personel operations. The deadline was extended to 7/31/2022. The following is a summary of outcomes during the total duration of the project.


The CU team designed, sourced, installed, and validated a custom  environmental chamber that integrated with our existing electro-dynamic  shaker.


The CU team worked closely with the Purdue University team in the  development of a triboelectric device that could withstand a wide range  of temperatures and relative humidity levels while attached to and  excited by an electro-dynamic shaker for long durations. Several  generations of such a device were developed with the final version made  on a thermal printer from PLA. Four different combinations of  triboelectric materials were explored in their performance.


The CU team develop and optimized a data acquisition system to record  triboelectric energy generator (TENG) output voltage and generator  acceleration.
 


The range and intervals for the environmental performance testing  were established and the triboelectric generator vibration performance  testing was completed. The data analysis was performed and three  important observations were made. The details of the observations are  reported in the significant findings section.


The humidity and temperature effect on the output behavior of the  triboelectric generator was sucessfully characterized for the harmonic  vibration input considered.


The following paper was presented at SMASIS 17 in Snowbird, UT resulting from preliminary work on this project.

Gauntt S., Batt G.,GibertJ., Dynamic Modeling of Triboelectric Generators Using Lagranges Equation,ASME Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS 17), Snowbird, UT,September 18-20, 2017.



A graduate student, Andrea Fisher, was recruited, trained, and completed her M.S Thesis on this project.


A graduate student,Travis Vaughan, was recruited and trained to continue the research of M.S. Packaging Science student, Andrea Fisher, since she graduated in May 2019. (Travis completed a year of work on the project before leaving the research program for a job offer in industry.)


A graduate student, Madysn Cardinal, was recuited and trained to complete the development of a middle school science demonstration/class on triboelectric energy generators. This demonstration/class was never delivered due to COVID school restrictions.


Sourced and purchased a 3D printer and computer workstation with the capability of printing electrical conductive materialsso we could continue devleopment of an optimized triboelectric generator.


Assembled and trained a team of undergraduate students to develop a  tribo-electric generator display for use at an industry trade show,  PACK EXPO, in Las Vegas. This display was presented throughout the event, September 2729, 2021. 


Submitted a manuscript of a journal paper for peer review. This paper is currently under review.

Barry, A.L, Batt, G.S., Gibert, J.M., Darby, D.O., The Application of  Triboelectric Energy Harvester in the Packaged Product Vibration  Environment, Packaging Technology and Science.Status: UNDER_REVIEW
